Award.AwardTitle: Asymptotic theory for stochastic processes via martingale methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
An important technique for establishing limit theorems for dependent sequences is to approximate them with well understood structures, such as martingales. Stationary martingale approximation is a subfield of stochastic processes that received a lot of attention in the last decade. Motivated by the study of asymptotic properties of nonstationary processes and also of stationary processes that cannot be approximated by stationary martingales, we shall develop the theory of nonstationary martingale approximations, which unites all the parts of the project. The new method will exploit blocking techniques to break the dependence and a new type of martingale construction based on blocks of variables. We shall also provide maximal inequalities, including Rosenthal-type inequalities, which are important for obtaining rates of convergence in the asymptotic results and facilitate the study of a stochastic process by approximating it, in the almost sure sense, with sums of independent normal random variables. These tools are fundamental for obtaining new projective criteria for stochastic processes that insure asymptotic results, including the conditional functional central limit theorem, limit theorems started at a point, moderate and large deviation results as well as exact representations for the tail probabilities of sums of random variables. These types of asymptotic behaviors are at the heart of probability theory with important applications to statistics and other applied fields.

The proposed project is expected to provide new mathematical ideas and techniques that will shed new light on several difficult open problems for stochastic processes and will impact other fields of research as follows: The limit theorems started at a point are useful to analyze random walks in a random environment. They are also of interest to researchers working in statistical mechanics, physics, and will lead to new discoveries for some interesting intermittent maps that recently came to the attention of specialists in dynamical systems. The results will be applicable to families of Metropolis-Hastings algorithms that are essential, for instance, for Bayesian statistics. The exact asymptotic representation for the tail probabilities will facilitate the estimations of deviation probabilities that occur in a natural way in many applied areas, so for instance, in problems of insurance in the context of large claim insurance, in risk theory and finance. The results will be disseminated broadly through publications in top rated journals and presentations in national and international conferences. They will also be integrated with training of graduate students, presented in weekly seminars, and will enter the curriculum of a course on limit theory for stochastic processes. Related questions are actively being studied by several groups of researchers, in the US and in Europe, and the proposed project will contribute to strengthen international scientific exchange and collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research is concerned with phenomena that evolve in time and in addition exhibit an inherent random variation. Very often, not only the evolutions, but also the environments in which they evolve present random variabilities. The first goal accomplished by this research was to point out suitable probabilistic models which describe evolutions in random environment. The second goal achieved was to analyze these models in order to better understand these evolutions and to predict future outcomes.

More specifically, the research mostly deals with the analysis of random walks in random environment. A random walk is a mathematical formalization of a path that consists of a succession of random steps. For example, the learning process is a result of consecutive levels which have a positive influence one on another. Also the path traced by a molecule as it travels in a liquid or a gas, the price of a fluctuating stock, the financial status of a gambler or the evolution of a writer’s vocabulary can all be modeled as random walks.  

Random walks in random environment has originally been introduced as a model for motions in disordered media, for the replication of DNA chains, and for phase transitions in alloys among others. We developed complex tools to treat random walks in random environment. We modeled these processes by interpreting them as evolutions which do not start from the equilibrium but are rather started from a fixed realization of the environment.

We analyzed the long time behavior of the model and convergence to equilibrium by developing a new technique based on methods which combine ideas from many fields of mathematics such as harmonic analyses, functional analysis and ergodic theory. We point out rates of convergence in the limit theorems. These are important since they give researchers and practitioners the confidence to apply long time behavior techniques. These results contribute to better predictions and make possible to evaluate their accuracy.

Due to their wide applicability, our discoveries concerning random walks have a broad impact. They are used in many fields: finance, actuarial, ecology, economics, psychology, computer science, physics, chemistry, biology, sociology, anthropology, geology, just to name a few. Random walks explain the observed behaviors of many processes in these fields, and thus serve as a fundamental model for the recorded stochastic activity.

The results on this research are presented in 16 new research papers by the principal investigator and her collaborators, including Ph.D. students. They are published or accepted for publication in well-established probability journals.

For fast dissemination, the results were presented at numerous national and international meetings and were well-received by the mathematical community. The PI collaborated on several problems with mathematicians from England and France, among others, contributing in this way to the international dissemination of these results.  

                The PI incorporated these research results in her courses and seminars and also in training Ph.D. students, which contributed to strengthening the education at the University of Cincinnati.
